revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Use British English|date=November 2013}} {{Politics of the Falkland Islands}}{{distinguish|Sovereignty of the Falkland Islands}} '''Falkland Islands status''' is a [[legal status]] in the [[Falkland Islands]] (the Falklands form of [[belonger status]]) defined by section 22(5) of the [[Falkland Islands Constitution]] and the Falkland Islands Status Ordinance, 2007 and is considered to be the closest thing to citizenship that the Falkland Islands can grant.<ref name="sartma">{{cite news | author=Juanita Brock | url=http://www.sartma.com/art_3618_12_377_2.html | title=Falklands : Executive Council Report for November2006 | work=sartma | date=16 November 2006 | accessdate=29 June 2013}}</ref><ref name="2009 Constitution">{{cite web |url=http://www.falklands.gov.fk/assets/The-Falkland-Islands-Constitution-Order-2008.pdf |title=Official text of the Falkland Islands Constitution Order 2008 |author= |date=1 January 2009 |work= |publisher=falklands.gov.fk |accessdate=2013-06-29 |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112201131/http://www.falklands.gov.fk/assets/The-Falkland-Islands-Constitution-Order-2008.pdf |archivedate=12 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="FINN"/> The [[Executive Council of the Falkland Islands]] considers applications for Status four times a year in January, April, July and October and advises the [[Governor of the Falkland Islands|Governor]] as to whether or not they may be granted.<ref name="FINN">{{cite news | author=Pete King| url=http://www.falklandnews.com/public/story.cfm?get=4645 | title=Falklands First Status Ceremony | work=Falkland Islands News Network | date=24 August 2007| accessdate=29 June 2013}}</ref> If the application is unsuccessful, the applicant has the right to appeal to the [[Supreme Court of the Falkland Islands]].<ref name="2009 Constitution" />
According to the 2012 census, a majority of those with Falkland Islands Status are [[British Citizens]], with 11% coming from 58 other countries (including 18 [[Argentine nationality law|Argentine nationals]]).<ref name="mercopress">{{cite news | url=http://en.mercopress.com/2013/06/28/falklands-referendum-voters-from-many-countries-around-the-world-voted-yes | title=Falklands Referendum: Voters from many countries around the world voted Yes | work=MercoPress | date=28 June 2013 | accessdate=29 June 2013}}</ref>
==Eligibility== ===Before 1 January 2009=== Before the current [[Falkland Islands Constitution]] came into force on 1 January 2009, Falkland Islands Status was defined by the 1985 Constitution, under which a person was eligible for Falkland Islands Status if they were:<ref name="2009 Constitution" /> *(a) a citizen who was born in the Falkland Islands; or *(b) a citizen who was born outside the Falkland Islands **(i) whose father or mother was born in the Falkland Islands; or **(ii) who is domiciled in the Falkland Islands and whose father or mother became, while resident in the Falkland Islands, a citizen by virtue of having been naturalised or registered as such or as a British subject or as a citizen of the United Kingdom and Colonies; or *(c) a citizen by virtue of having been so naturalised or registered while resident in the Falkland Islands; or *(d) a Commonwealth citizen who is domiciled in the Falkland Islands who either **(i) was ordinarily resident in the Falkland Islands for the seven years immediately preceding 1st September 1997; or **(ii) has been granted such status under the provisions of an Ordinance providing for the grant of that status to Commonwealth citizens who have been ordinarily resident in the Falkland Islands for a period of at least seven years and has not, in accordance with the provisions of that Ordinance, lost or been deprived of such status; or *(e) the spouse, widow or widower of such a person as is referred to in any of the preceding paragraphs of this subsection, and, in the case of a spouse, is not living apart from her husband or his wife, as the case may be, under a decree of a competent court or a deed of separation; or *(f) under the age of eighteen years and is the child, stepchild, or child adopted in a manner recognised by law, of such a person as is referred to in any of the preceding paragraphs of this subsection.
===After 1 January 2009=== Under section 22(5) of the current [[Falkland Islands Constitution]], a person is entitled to Falkland Islands status if they are:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Falkland_order1985.pdf |title=Official text of the Falkland Islands Constitution Order 1985 (as amended by the Falkland Islands Constitution (Amendment) Order 1997)|author= |date=18 April 1985 |work= |publisher=worldstatesmen.org |accessdate=2013-06-29| format =[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]}}</ref> *(a) a person who had Falkland Islands status before 1 January 2009— **(i) by virtue of section 17(5)(a), (b), (c), (d)(i) or (f) of the former Constitution; or **(ii) by virtue of section 17(5)(e) of the former Constitution— ***(aa) as a spouse, and the person is not living apart from his wife or her husband under a decree of a competent court or a deed of separation; or ***(bb) as a widow or widower, and the person has not remarried; or *(b) a person who was born in the Falkland Islands, who was a citizen at birth and whose father or mother was permanently resident in the Falkland Islands at the time of the person’s birth; or *(c) a person who was born outside the Falkland Islands, who was a citizen at birth and whose father or mother was permanently resident in the Falkland Islands at the time of the person’s birth; or *(d) a citizen who was born in or outside the Falkland Islands whose father or mother at the time of the person’s birth had Falkland Islands status and was permanently resident in the Falkland Islands; or *(e) a citizen who was born outside the Falkland Islands whose father or mother was born in the Falkland Islands and had Falkland Islands status at the time of the person’s birth; or *(f) a person who has been granted Falkland Islands status under an Ordinance providing for the grant of that status to persons who have been ordinarily resident in the Falkland Islands for a period of at least seven years, or such period not exceeding seven years as the Ordinance may prescribe, and has not, in accordance with that Ordinance, lost or been deprived of such status.
==Status Ceremonies== Since 2007, all new applicants for Falkland Islands Status, if their application is successful, must attend a Status Ceremony and make a pledge to the Falkland Islands, as follows:<ref name="sartma"/> {{quote|''I [name] pledge my loyalty to the Falkland Islands and will respect its rights and freedoms. I will uphold its democratic values. I will obey its laws and fulfil my duties and obligations under its Constitution.''<ref name="FINN"/>}}
Ceremonies, which are presided over by the [[Governor of the Falkland Islands]], normally take place within one month of approval of an application. The first ceremony took place on 17 August 2007.<ref name="FINN"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Status}} [[Category:Falkland Islands culture]] [[Category:Falkland Islands society]] [[Category:Nationality law in British Overseas Territories]] [[Category:Falkland Islands law]]

page.title: Fiction based on World War II

revision.text:
Many types of [[fiction]] have involved events in the [[World War II]] time period. This list is a chronological collection of significant events from such fiction. It includes events that were set in World War II but have never occurred. Many of these works are key examples of the [[war novel]] genre.
==Novels==
*''Stalin's Gold'' by [[Mark Ellis (Welsh author)|Mark Ellis (author)]] (1938) *''[[Moment in Peking]]'' by [[Lin Yutang]] (1939) *''Princes Gate'' by [[Mark Ellis (Welsh author)|Mark Ellis (author)]] (1940) *''[[Most Secret]]'' by [[Nevil Shute]] (1942) *''[[A Bell for Adano (novel)|A Bell for Adano]]'' by [[John Hersey]] (1944) *''[[Pastoral (1944 novel)|Pastoral]]'' by [[Nevil Shute]] (1944) *''Shore Leave'' by Frederick Wakeman (1944) *''[[Guard of Honor]]'' by [[James Gould Cozzens]] (1948) *''[[The Naked and the Dead]]'' by [[Norman Mailer]] (1948) *''[[The Caine Mutiny]]'' by [[Herman Wouk]] (1951) *''[[The Cruel Sea (book)|The Cruel Sea]]'' by [[Nicholas Monsarrat]] (1951) *''[[From Here to Eternity]]'' by [[James Jones (author)|James Jones]] (1951) *''[[The Bridge over the River Kwai (novel)|The Bridge over the River Kwai]]'' by [[Pierre Boulle]] (1954) *''[[The Charioteer]]'' by [[Mary Renault]] (1954) *''[[The Good Shepherd (nautical fiction)|The Good Shepherd]]'' by [[C. S. Forester]] (1955) *''[[HMS Ulysses (novel)|HMS Ulysses]]'' by [[Alistair MacLean]] (1955) *''[[Run Silent, Run Deep]]'' by [[Edward L. Beach, Jr.]] (1955) *''[[The War Lover (novel)|The War Lover]]'' by [[John Hersey]] (1959) *''[[The Great Fortune]]'' by Olivier Manning (1960) *''[[Catch-22]]'' by [[Joseph Heller]] (1961) *''[[Goodbye to Some]]'' by [[Gordon Forbes]] (1961) *''[[King Rat (1962 novel)|King Rat]]'' by [[James Clavell]] (1962) *''[[The Thin Red Line (1962 novel)|The Thin Red Line]]'' by James Jones (1962) *''[[The High White Forest]]'' by [[Ralph Allen (journalist)|Ralph Allen]] (1964) *''The Secret of Santa Vittoria'' by [[Robert Crichton (novelist)|Robert Crichton]] (1966) *''[[Once an Eagle (novel)|Once an Eagle]]'' by [[Anton Myrer]] (1968) *''[[Slaughterhouse Five]]'' by [[Kurt Vonnegut]] Jr. (1969) *''[[The Winds of War]]'' by Herman Wouk (1971) *''[[Gravity's Rainbow]]'' by [[Thomas Pynchon]] (1973) *''[[The Rhinemann Exchange]]'' by [[Robert Ludlum]] (1974) *''[[The Eagle Has Landed (novel)|The Eagle Has Landed]]'' by [[Jack Higgins]] (1975) *''[[Eye of the Needle (novel)|Eye of the Needle]]'' by [[Ken Follett]] (1978) *''[[War and Remembrance]]'' by Herman Wouk (1978) *''[[Whistle (novel)|Whistle]]'' by James Jones (1978) *''[[No Birds Sang]]'' by [[Farley Mowat]] (1979) *''[[Goodnight Mister Tom]]'' by Michelle Margorian (1981) *''[[Lessons in Dance and Love]]'' by [[Pavel Kohout]] (1989) *''[[Number the stars]] by [[Lois Lowry]] (1989) *''[[Führer (novel)|Führer]]'' by Alan Prior (about [[Adolf Hitler|Hitler]]) (1991) *''No Man's Land'' by [[Kevin Major]] (1995) *''[[A Walk in the Sun (novel)|A Walk in the Sun]]'' by [[Harry Brown (writer)|Harry Brown]] (1998) *''[[The Book of Kings (novel)|The Book of Kings]]'' by [[James Thackara]] (1999) *''[[War of the Rats]]'' by [[David L. Robbins (of Virginia)|David L. Robbins]] (1999) *''[[The Widow Killer]]'' by Pavel Kohout (1995 in Czech, 2000 in English) *''The Cloud Atlas'' by Liam Callanan (2004) *''[[The Book Thief]]'' by [[Markus Zusak]] (2007) *''[[The Far Reaches]]'' by [[Homer Hickam]] (2007) *''[[The Steel Wave]]'' by [[Jeff Shaara]] (2008) *''[[Blackout/All Clear]]'' by [[Connie Willis]] (2010) *''[[Showa: Chronicles of a Fallen God]]'' by Paul-Yanic Laquerre (about [[Hirohito]]) (2013) *''[[Save me Twice - Based on a True Story]]'' by [[Elfriede Dustin]] (2016) *In Apple Blossom Time<ref>https://www.amazon.com/In-Apple-Blossom-Time-ebook/dp/B00DAGT2PK</ref> by Robert Wack (2013)
===Authors who specialize in World War II=== *[[Mark Ellis (Welsh author)|Mark Ellis]] *[[Sven Hassel]] *[[Philip Kerr]] *[[Arnošt Lustig]]
==Short stories==
*''[[Tales of the South Pacific]]'' by [[James Michener]] (1947) *''[[For Esmé – with Love and Squalor]]'' by [[J.D. Salinger]] (1950) *''[[Sofiah]]'' by [[Rob Shepherd]] (2013)
==Movies== {{main|List of world war II films}}
===1930s=== *''[[Confessions of a Nazi Spy]]'' (1939) *''[[Hitler – Beast of Berlin]]'' (1939)
===1940s=== *''[[Night Train to Munich]]'' (1940) *''[[The Great Dictator]]'' (1940) *''[[Man Hunt (1941 film)|Man Hunt]]'' (1941) *''[[Casablanca (film)|Casablanca]]'' (1942) *''[[To Have and Have Not (film)|To Have and Have Not]]'' (1944) *''[[Objective, Burma!]]'' (1945) *''[[Command Decision (film)|Command Decision]]'' (1948) *''[[Twelve O'Clock High]]'' (1949)
===1950s=== *''[[The Men (film)|The Men]]'' (1950) *''[[Force of Arms]]'' (1951) *''[[Submarine Command]]'' (1951) *''[[Stalag 17]]'' (1953) *''[[From Here to Eternity]]'' (1953) *''[[The Sea Chase]]'' (1955) *''[[Mister Roberts (1955 film)|Mister Roberts]]'' (1955) *''[[Heaven Knows, Mr. Allison]]'' (1957) *''[[Run Silent, Run Deep (1958 film)|Run Silent, Run Deep]]'' (1958) *''[[Operation Petticoat]]'' (1959)
===1960s=== *''[[The Guns of Navarone (film)|The Guns of Navarone]]'' (1961) *''[[The Thin Red Line (1964 film)|The Thin Red Line]]'' (1964) *''[[War Italian Style]]'' (1965) *''[[Closely Watched Trains]]'' (1966) *''[[The Dirty Dozen]]'' (1967) *''[[The Devil's Brigade (film)|The Devil's Brigade]]'' (1968)
===1970s=== *''[[Catch-22 (film)|Catch-22]]'' (1970) *''[[Kelly's Heroes]]'' (1970) *''[[Once An Eagle]]'' (1976) *''[[Cross of Iron]]'' (1977) *''[[Force 10 from Navarone (film)|Force 10 from Navarone]]'' (1978) *''[[1941 (film)|1941]]'' (1979)
===1980s=== *''[[The Sea Wolves]]'' (1980) *''[[Das Boot (film)|Das Boot]]'' (1981) *''[[Eye of the Needle (film)|Eye of the Needle]]'' (1981) *''[[Come and See]]'' (1985) *''The Misfit Brigad'' (1987) *''[[Empire of the Sun (film)|Empire of the Sun]]'' (film)
===1990s=== *''[[Captain America (1990 film)|Captain America]]'' (1990) *''[[Schindler's List]]'' (1993) *''[[Stalingrad (1993 film)|Stalingrad]]'' (1993) *''[[La vita e' bella]]'' (1997) *''Goodnight Mister Tom'' (1998) (starring [[John Thaw]]) *''[[Saving Private Ryan]]'' (1998) *''[[The Thin Red Line (1998 film)|The Thin Red Line]]'' (1998) *''[[All My Loved Ones]]'' (1999) (about [[Nicholas Winton]])
===2000s=== *''[[Divided We Fall (film)|Divided We Fall]]'' (2000) *''[[Enemy at the Gates]]'' (2001) *''[[Pearl Harbor (film)|Pearl Harbor]] (2001) *''[[Windtalkers]]'' (2002) *''[[Želary]]'' (2003) *''[[Flags of Our Fathers (film)|Flags of Our Fathers]]'' (2006) *''[[Letters from Iwo Jima]]'' (2006) *''[[Miracle at St. Anna]]'' (2008) *''[[Defiance (2008 film)|Defiance]]'' (2008) *''[[Valkyrie (film)|Valkyrie]]'' (2008) *''[[The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas (film)|The Boy in The Striped Pyjamas]]'' (2008) *''[[Inglourious Basterds]]'' (2009)
===2010s=== *''[[Captain America: The First Avenger]]'' (2011) *''[[Red Tails]]'' (2012) *''[[The Book Thief (film)|The Book Thief]]'' (2013) *''[[Fury (2014 film)|Fury]]'' (2014) *''[[Allied (film)|Allied]]'' (2016) *''[[Dunkirk (2017 film)|Dunkirk]]'' (2017)
==Games== *''[[Call of Duty]]'' *''[[Medal of Honor series]]'' *''[[Men of War (video game)|Men of War]]'' and its expansions *''[[Wolfenstein 3D|Wolfenstein]]'' video game series by [[Id Software]] *''[[UberSoldier]]'' *''[[Battlefield 1942]]'' *''[[Day Of Defeat]]'' and its upgraded, [[Source Engine]] counterpart, ''[[Day of Defeat: Source]]'' *''[[Company of Heroes]]'' and its expansions *''[[Red Orchestra: Ostfront 41-45]] *''[[Hidden & Dangerous]]''
==Comic books== *[[Marvel Comics|Marvel]] superheroes fight Nazi Germany, including [[Captain America]], [[Sgt. Fury and his Howling Commandos]], etc.
==Manga/anime== *''[[Hetalia: Axis Powers]]'' *''[[Zipang (anime)]]'' *''[[Zipang (manga)]]''
==TV series== {{main|List of World War II TV series}}
==See also== *[[Nazis in fiction]] *[[War novel]] *[[List of films based on war books]] *[[Fiction based on World War I]] *[[Fiction based on the Vietnam War]] *[[Alternate history (fiction)|Alternate history]] *[[:Category:Lists of World War II films]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{refimprove|date=July 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox organization | name = Goge Africa | logo = GogeAfrica.jpg | logo_size = 200px | type = Cultural Institution | founded_date = {{start date and age|df=yes|1999}} | founders = Isaac and Nneka Moses | headquarters = [[Lagos]], Nigeria | origins = | key_people = Isaac Moses
[[Nneka Moses]] | area_served = Africa | product = African music, dance, food, clothes and tourism | focus = | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = "A celebration of Africa's heritage" | homepage = [http://www.gogeafrica.tv/ www.gogeafrica.tv] | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''Goge Africa''' (GA) is an award-winning [[pan-African]] tourism and cultural programme, which was founded in the year 1999. It was conceptualized and anchor by a [[Nigerian]] couple, Isaac and Nneka Moses. The program is watched by over 40millions television (TV) viewers across the globe. On 1 October 1999, GA premiered on Nigerian TV ;[[African Independent Television]] (AIT), [[Nigerian Television Authority]] (NTA) Channel 10, and [[Degue Broadcasting Network]] (DBN).It was later aired on [[M-Net|MNET AFRICA MAGIC]]. The recording of GA started in Nigeria and moved to [[Benin Republic]],South Africa and [[Egypt]] with the plan to cover all countries in Africa.The show was established to showcase the richness of African culture, dance, food, [[clothes]] and tourism. In the year 2016, the Nigerian Broadcasters Merit award (NBMA) inducted the two presenters of the program into Nigerian [[Broadcasting|Broadcasters]] Hall of Fame. In 2005, the organization launched GA foundation with the aim of mentoring Nigerian youths. ==Background== [[File:Wiki Loves Africa 2016 (Nigeria) 024.jpg|thumb|Wiki Loves Africa 2016 (Nigeria) 024| Isaac and Nneka Moses, program coordinators| right]] Goge Africa was founded by the duo of Isaac and [[Nneka Moses]] as a [[pan African]] cultural project. The program was conceptualized with aim of promoting African culture, music, food and her ways of life through television, radio and magazines. The name "Goge Africa", was culled from a musical instrument common among musicians from Northern part of Nigeria called [[Goge]].{{cite web|last1=Sumaila|first1=Isah Umasha|title=Goge Africa is a life time project (interview)|url=http://everythinliterature.blogspot.com.ng/2007/12/goge-africa-is-life-time-project.html|publisher=Everythinliterature|accessdate=1 December 2016}} According to AIT, goge Africa... "Goge Africa, every tribe, every African culture and tradition is brought to light in a celebratory and joyous manner. Africa has never looked more beautiful than it does on this wonderful show.".{{cite web|last1=kakaki Segment|title=……a celebration of Africa's heritage|url=http://www.aitonline.tv/program-goge_africa|publisher=Africa Independent Television|accessdate=1 December 2016}} The TV version of the program started in the year 1999 when African programs were not popular on Nigerian TV.{{cite web|last1=CHUKS|first1=NWANNE|title=The Princess of Goge Africa|url=http://logbaby.com/news/the-princess-of-goge-africa_8098.html#.WEh-ZX2o2I5|publisher=LOGBABY.COM|accessdate=1 December 2016}} The show is watched by over 40millions television viewers across the globe. In 2016, the two presenters of the show were inducted into the [[Hall of Fame]] by NBMA.{{cite web|last1=Admin|url=http://www.nigerianbroadcastersmeritawards.com/behold-winners-at-6th-nigerian-broadcasters-merit-awards-nbma/|title=BEHOLD! Winners at 6th Nigerian Broadcasters Merit Awards (NBMA)|publisher=Nigerian Broadcasters Merit Award|accessdate= 1 December 2016}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/user/gogeafricatv Goge Africatv on Youtube] [[Category:Companies based in Lagos]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Nigeria]] [[Category:Cultural organisations in Nigeria]] [[Category:Cultural promotion organizations]]

revision.text:
The {{nihongo|'''''Guild''''' series|ギルドシリーズ|Girudo Shirīzu}} is a [[Bundled software|compilation]] of video games produced by [[Level-5 (video game company)|Level-5]] for the [[Nintendo 3DS]] in cooperation with various game designers. The first compilation, {{nihongo|'''''Guild01'''''|ギルド01|Girudo Zero Wan}},{{cite web|url=http://level5ia.com/news/level5-vision-2011-recap/|title=Level5 Vision 2011 Recap|accessdate=2011-10-29|publisher=Level-5 International America|year=2011}}{{cite video game|title=Guild 01|developer=[[Level-5 (video game company)|Level-5]]|developer2=[[Grasshopper Manufacture]]|developer3=[[Vivarium Inc.]]|publisher= Level-5|date=2012-05-31|platform=[[Nintendo 3DS]]|version=|scene=|level=|language=Japanese|isolang=|quote=}} consists of four games and was released at retail in Japan on May 31, 2012.{{cite web|url=http://andriasang.com/comyj5/|title=Suda 51, Yasumi Matsuno and Yoot Saito Team Up For Level-5's Guild 01|accessdate=2011-10-29|publisher=Andriasang|year=2011|author=Gantayat, Anoop}}{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/news/level-5-releasing-3ds-indie-game-bundle|title=Level-5 Releasing 3DS Indie-Game Bundle of Sorts|accessdate=2011-10-29|publisher=1UP.com|year=2011|author=Gifford, Kevin|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111130212037/http://www.1up.com/news/level-5-releasing-3ds-indie-game-bundle|archivedate=2011-11-30|df=}} Three of the titles have been announced for individual release on the [[Nintendo eShop]] in Western territories during Fall 2012.{{cite web |url=http://kotaku.com/5949045/nintendos-3ds-eshop-line+up-for-the-rest-of-2012-is-spectacular?post=53235018 |title=Nintendo's 3DS eShop Line-Up For The Rest of 2012 Is Spectacular |first=Stephen |last=Totilo |date=October 4, 2012 |work=[[Kotaku]] |accessdate=2012-12-05}} All four of them were released individually on the Japanese eShop not long after. A second compilation, {{nihongo|'''''Guild02'''''|ギルド02|Girudo Zero Tsū}}, which features three games designed by [[Keiji Inafune]], Kazuya Asano, Takemaru Abiko and Kaz Ayabe, was released on the Nintendo eShop in Japan during March 2013 and began releasing in Western territories in May 2013.{{cite web|url=http://gematsu.com/2012/08/level-5-america-trademarks-two-guild-01-titles|title=Level-5 America trademarks two Guild 01 titles|accessdate=2012-08-13|publisher=Gematsu|year=2012|author=Sal Romano}}{{cite web|url=http://m.joystiq.com/2013/05/04/first-guild02-game-coming-to-3ds-eshop-on-may-16/ |title=First Guild02 game coming to 3DS eShop on May 16 - JoyStiq |publisher=M.joystiq.com |date=2013-05-04 |accessdate=2013-05-19}} ==''Guild01''== {{Infobox video game |title = Guild01 |image = [[File:Guild01 Logo.png|200px]] |developer = [[Level-5 (video game company)|Level-5]]
[[Grasshopper Manufacture]] (Liberation Maiden)
[[Vivarium Inc.]] (Aero Porter)
[[Nex Entertainment]] (Weapon Shop de Omasse, Crimson Shroud){{cite web|url=http://www.nex-ent.co.jp/contents/consumer.html|title=Nex Entertainment Consumer Products list|accessdate=17 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Bhj5DltQ?url=http://www.nex-ent.co.jp/contents/consumer.html|archivedate=26 October 2012|df=}} |publisher = Level-5 |designer = [[Goichi Suda]] (Liberation Maiden)
[[America Zarigani|Yoshiyuki Hirai]] (Rental Bukiya de Omasse)
[[Yoot Saito]] (Aero Porter)
[[Yasumi Matsuno]] (Crimson Shroud) |composer = [[Basiscape]] (Crimson Shroud) |released = '''As Guild01'''
{{vgrelease|JP|May 31, 2012{{cite web|url=http://andriasang.com/con04i/|title=Level-5's Guild 01 Set for May 17|accessdate=February 28, 2012|publisher=Andriasang|year=2012|author=Gantayat, Anoop}}}} '''Nintendo eShop'''
{{vgrelease|JP|November 14, 2012|NA|October 25, 2012|EU|October 4, 2012}} |genre = [[Compilation (games)|Compilation]], [[role-playing game]], [[shoot 'em up]], [[Simulation game|simulation]] |modes = |platforms = [[Nintendo 3DS]] }} ''Guild01'' was released as a compilation for Nintendo 3DS in Japan on May 31, 2012 and consists of four completely distinct games, designed by [[Goichi Suda]], [[Yoot Saito]], [[Yasumi Matsuno]] and Yoshiyuki Hirai of comedy duo [[America Zarigani]].{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5848948/a-new-3ds-game-with-four-games-in-it-made-by-four-different-creators|title=A New 3DS Game with Four Games in it, Made by Four Different Creators|accessdate=2011-10-29|publisher=Kotaku|year=2011|author=Ashcraft, Brian}} The game was bundled with a playable demo of Level-5's game, ''[[Time Travelers (2012 video game)|Time Travelers]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2012-04-24/level-5-guild01-game-promo-video-posted |title=Level-5's Guild01 Game's Promo Video Posted |date=April 24, 2012 |work=[[Anime News Network]] |accessdate=2012-12-05}} They were later released on the Nintendo eShop in late 2012, with the exception of 'Weapon Shop de Omasse,' which was released in February 2014. ===''Liberation Maiden''=== {{Main|Liberation Maiden}} ===''Aero Porter''=== {{nihongo|''Aero Porter''|エアロポーター|Earo Pōtā}} is a [[simulation game]] directed by Yoot Saito. The player is in charge of an [[airport]], and their goal is to manage baggage quickly and ensure that the airplanes are able to depart on time. If the player is successful, their airport's rating will grow, gaining them more money and passengers as well as allowing them to purchase new airplanes and expand their airport. The game was released in North America, Europe and Australasia on November 29, 2012 and individually in Japan on December 5, 2012. ===''Crimson Shroud''=== {{nihongo|''Crimson Shroud''|クリムゾンシュラウド|Kurimuzon Shuraudo}} is a traditional [[adventure game|adventure]] [[role-playing game|RPG]] created by [[Yasumi Matsuno]], developed internally at [[Level-5 (video game company)|Level-5]]{{cite web|url=http://andriasang.com/comyka/|title=First Look: Guild 01|accessdate=2011-10-29|publisher=Andriasang|year=2011|author=Gantayat, Anoop}} alongside [[Nex Entertainment]]. The player is a "Chaser", someone who is an expert at searching for people. The game is set 1,000 years in the past in a world without magic, and the story details how magic became commonplace in its world. The game was released on the Nintendo eShop in Japan on November 28, 2012 and in North America, Europe and Australasia on December 13, 2012. The game features music by [[Hitoshi Sakimoto]]'s company, Basiscape, with music from him, Mitsuhiro Kaneda, Azusa Chiba, Kimihiro Abe, and [[Masaharu Iwata]].{{cite web|title=CRIMSONSHROUD Original Soundtrack|url=http://vgmdb.net/album/32688|publisher=VGMdn.net|accessdate=7 March 2014}} ===''Weapon Shop de Omasse''=== {{nihongo|''Weapon Shop de Omasse''|レンタル武器屋 de オマッセ|Rentaru Bukiya de Omasse|lit. ''Omasse's Rental Weapon Shop''}} is a [[fantasy]] [[rhythm game|rhythm]] [[role-playing game|RPG]] written by Yoshiyuki Hirai, in which the main characters are a father and son pair who craft weapons for heroes. The player uses rhythmic gameplay to forge weapons which are rented by heroes for their quests; the weapon chosen will affect whether or not the hero is successful.{{cite web|url=http://andriasang.com/comyj8/|title=More Guild 01 Details|accessdate=2011-10-29|publisher=Andriasang|year=2011|author=Gantayat, Anoop}} The game was released individually on the Japanese Nintendo eShop on November 21, 2012. Originally, this was the only title not to be announced for Western release, with the publisher citing the high degree of translation required and debatable audience size for the game for a localization to be produced.{{cite web|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2012/11/15/why-omasse-rental-weapon-shop-wasnt-localized-and-other-guild01-questions/ |title=Why Omasse Rental Weapon Shop Wasn't Localized And Other Guild01 Questions |publisher=Siliconera.com |date=2012-11-15 |accessdate=2015-05-21}} In January 2014, a classification of the game was posted by the [[Australian Classification Board]] under the title, ''Weapon Shop de Omasse'', suggesting that the game would receive a localization.{{cite web|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2014/01/08/level-5-localizing-missing-guild-01-game-weapon-shop-de-omasse/ |title=Level-5 Is Localizing Missing Guild 01 Game Weapon Shop De Omasse |publisher=Siliconera.com |date=2014-01-08 |accessdate=2015-05-21}} The game was released on February 20, 2014 after the announcement during a [[List of Nintendo Direct presentations|Nintendo Direct]] on February 13, 2014. {{clear}} ==''Guild02''== {{Infobox video game | title = Guild02 | image = [[File:Guild02 Logo.jpg|200px]] | developer = [[Level-5 (video game company)|Level-5]]
[[Millennium Kitchen]] and [[Aquria]] {{cite web|url=http://www.aquria.co.jp/works.html |accessdate=March 31, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140226092924/http://www.aquria.co.jp/works.html |archivedate=February 26, 2014 }} (Attack of the Friday Monsters!)
[[Level-5 Comcept|Comcept]] and [[Natsume (company)|Natsume]]{{cite web|url=http://www.natsumeatari.co.jp/results/results_natsume.html |title=ナツメアタリ株式会社｜制作実績 |publisher=Natsumeatari.co.jp |date= |accessdate=2015-05-21}} (Bugs vs. Tanks) | publisher = Level-5 | designer = [[Keiji Inafune]] (Bugs vs. Tanks)
Kaz Ayabe (Attack of the Friday Monsters!)
Kazuya Asano, Takemaru Abiko (The Starship Damrey) | released = {{vgrelease|JP|March 13, 2013|NA|May 16, 2013|EU|May 16, 2013|AUS|May 16, 2013}} | genre = [[Compilation (games)|Compilation]], [[tank simulation game|tank sim]], [[survival horror]], [[life simulation game|life sim]] | modes = | platforms = [[Nintendo 3DS]] }} A follow-up title, titled ''Guild02'', was announced on May 24, 2012. The compilation features three games designed by [[Keiji Inafune]], Kazuya Asano, Takemaru Abiko and Kaz Ayabe.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2012-05-23/kenji-inafune-other-creators-announced-as-working-on-guild02-game |title=Keiji Inafune, Other Creators Announced as Working on Guild02 Game |date=May 23, 2012 |work=[[Anime News Network]] |accessdate=2012-12-05}} The compilation has not been announced for a retail release. These games were released on the Nintendo eShop in Japan in March 2013, and in North America, Europe and Australasia in May 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2013/04/17-1/level-5s-guild-02-3ds-eshop-games-announced-for-western-release |title=Level-5's "Guild 02" 3DS eShop Games Announced for Western Release |publisher=Crunchyroll |date=2013-04-18 |accessdate=2013-05-19}} Each ''Guild02'' game has bonus content which can be accessed if save data for any ''Guild01'' game is detected. ===''Attack of the Friday Monsters!''=== {{nihongo|''Attack of the Friday Monsters!''|怪獣が出る金曜日|Kaijū ga Deru Kinyōbi|lit. ''The Friday When Monsters Appear''}} is a life simulation game designed by Kaz Ayabe, who is known in Japan for the popular ''[[Boku no Natsuyasumi]]'' series. The game follows a boy named Sohta who lives in a town where monsters and superheroes from 1970s [[tokusatsu]] shows appear every Friday. The game was released in Japan on March 13, 2013 and in North America, Europe and Australasia on July 18, 2013. ===''Bugs vs. Tanks''=== {{nihongo|''Bugs vs. Tanks''|虫けら戦車|Mushikera Sensha}} is a tank action game designed by [[Keiji Inafune]].{{cn|date=June 2017}} The game sees players take the role of various [[World War II]] tanks piloted by Nazi soldiers that have been shrunk down to miniature size in order to fight against various bugs and insects. The game was released in Japan on March 19, 2013 and in North America, Europe and Australasia on June 20, 2013. ===''The Starship Damrey''=== {{nihongo|''The Starship Damrey''|宇宙船ダムレイ号|Uchūsen Damurei-gō}} is a first-person perspective survival horror game designed by Kazuya Asano and Takemaru Abiko. The game throws players into a suspenseful environment with no tutorials or hints to guide them. The game was released in Japan on March 27, 2013 and in North America, Europe and Australasia on May 16, 2013.{{cite web|last=Matulef |first=Jeffrey |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-05-09-level-5s-horror-adventure-curio-the-starship-damrey-due-next-week-on-3ds-eshop |title=Level-5's horror adventure curio The Starship Damrey due next week on 3DS eShop • News • 3DS • |publisher=Eurogamer.net |date=2013-05-09 |accessdate=2013-05-19}}{{-}} ==Reception== ''[[Famitsu]]'' gave ''Guild01'' a score of 34/40.{{cite web |url=http://gematsu.com/2012/05/famitsu-review-scores-issue-1225 |title=Famitsu Review Scores: Issue 1225 - Gematsu |accessdate=2012-12-05}} In an import review, [[ComputerAndVideoGames.com]] gave the game a score of 7.5, saying that whilst the individual games have a lot of charm, the differences between them are too great for them to work as a single package.{{cite web|url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/361891/reviews/guild-01-review-japans-greatest-development-talents-fail-to-hit-gold-review/|title=Guild 01 review: Japan's greatest development talents fail to hit gold|first=Daniel|last=Robson|date=11 August 2012|work=[[Computer and Video Games]]|accessdate=2012-12-05}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{portal|2010s|Video games}} *{{official website|http://www.guild-series.jp/}} {{jp icon}} **{{official website|http://www.level5.co.jp/products/guild01/index.html|''Guild01'' website}} {{jp icon}} **{{official website|http://www.level5.co.jp/products/guild/guild02.html|''Guild02'' website}} {{jp icon}} {{Level-5|state=expanded}} {{Grasshopper Manufacture}} [[Category:2012 video games]] [[Category:2013 video games]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:Kaiju video games]] [[Category:Level-5 (company) games]] [[Category:Nintendo 3DS games]] [[Category:Nintendo 3DS eShop games]] [[Category:Nintendo 3DS-only games]] [[Category:Psychological horror games]] [[Category:Simulation video games]] [[Category:Single-player video games]] [[Category:Video game compilations]] [[Category:Video game franchises]] [[Category:Video games scored by Hitoshi Sakimoto]] [[Category:Video games scored by Masaharu Iwata]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games featuring female protagonists]] [[Category:Video game franchises introduced in 2012]] [[Category:Fiction about size change]] [[Category:Fictional guilds]]
